metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: The writing of balanced half-equations (including states) for oxidation and reduction reactions, and the overall redox cell reaction in both acidic and basic conditions

oxidation_electron_position.name: Electrons in Oxidation Half-Equations
oxidation_electron_position.correct: In oxidation half-equations, electrons appear on the RIGHT-HAND side as products because oxidation is loss of electrons (OIL).

left-hand side as reactants.fix: Oxidation Is Loss. The species LOSES electrons, so electrons appear as products on the right.
left-hand side as reactants.action: Write Zn → Zn²⁺. Zinc lost 2 electrons, so add 2e⁻ to the right: Zn → Zn²⁺ + 2e⁻

on both sides.error: Electrons appear on only ONE side of a half-equation.
on both sides.fix: Half-equations show either gain OR loss, not both. Both sides would cancel out.
on both sides.action: Check: if electrons are on both sides, something is wrong with your equation.

not shown in the equation.error: Electrons must be shown in half-equations.
not shown in the equation.fix: Half-equations explicitly show electron transfer. That's what makes them half-equations.
not shown in the equation.action: The whole point of half-equations is to show electrons. Always include them.

persistent.gap: You're confusing which side electrons appear on for oxidation vs reduction.
persistent.action: Memorise OILRIG: Oxidation Is Loss (electrons on right), Reduction Is Gain (electrons on left).

reduction_electron_position.name: Electrons in Reduction Half-Equations
reduction_electron_position.correct: In reduction half-equations, electrons appear on the LEFT-HAND side as reactants because reduction is gain of electrons (RIG).

right-hand side as products.fix: Reduction Is Gain. The species GAINS electrons, so electrons must be reactants on the left.
right-hand side as products.action: Write Cu²⁺ → Cu. Copper gained 2 electrons, so add 2e⁻ to the left: Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu

on both sides.error: Electrons appear on only ONE side of a half-equation.
on both sides.fix: Half-equations show either gain OR loss. Electrons on both sides would cancel.
on both sides.action: Check your equation. Electrons should appear on only one side.

not shown in the equation.error: Electrons must be explicitly shown in half-equations.
not shown in the equation.fix: The purpose of half-equations is to show electron transfer clearly.
not shown in the equation.action: Always include electrons. Without them, it's not a proper half-equation.

persistent.gap: You're confusing oxidation and reduction electron positions.
persistent.action: Write 10 half-equations. Label each as oxidation or reduction based on electron position.

simple_half_equation_steps.name: ECS Method for Simple Half-Equations
simple_half_equation_steps.correct: For simple half-equations (one element), use ECS: balance Elements, balance Charges with electrons, add States.

States → Charges → Elements.error: Wrong order. You can't add states until the equation is balanced.
States → Charges → Elements.fix: ECS order: Elements first, then Charges (electrons), finally States.
States → Charges → Elements.action: Balance atoms first, then make charges equal, then add (s), (l), (aq), (g).

Charges → Elements → States.error: You must balance atoms before worrying about charge.
Charges → Elements → States.fix: ECS: Elements come first. You need correct coefficients before adding electrons.
Charges → Elements → States.action: Step 1: How many atoms each side? Step 2: What's the charge difference? Step 3: States.

add water and hydrogen ions.error: That's for complex half-equations in acidic conditions, not simple ones.
add water and hydrogen ions.fix: Simple half-equations have only one element. No need for H₂O or H⁺.
add water and hydrogen ions.action: Simple = one element (like Zn → Zn²⁺). Complex = multiple elements (like MnO₄⁻).

persistent.gap: You're mixing up methods for simple vs complex half-equations.
persistent.action: Learn to identify: one element = ECS method. Multiple elements = KOHES method.

kohes_method.name: KOHES Method for Acidic Conditions
kohes_method.formula: Key element → Oxygen → Hydrogen → Electrons → States
kohes_method.correct: For complex half-equations in acidic conditions, use KOHES: balance Key element, Oxygen (with H₂O), Hydrogen (with H⁺), Electrons, States.

balance hydrogen before oxygen.error: Wrong order. Oxygen must be balanced before hydrogen.
balance hydrogen before oxygen.fix: KOHES order: K, then O (add H₂O), then H (add H⁺). Adding H₂O first creates H to balance.
balance hydrogen before oxygen.action: Add H₂O to balance O. This introduces H atoms. Then add H⁺ to balance those H atoms.

balance electrons before hydrogen.error: Electrons come after H in KOHES.
balance electrons before hydrogen.fix: You need all atoms balanced before you can determine the charge difference for electrons.
balance electrons before hydrogen.action: Complete K-O-H first. Count total charge on each side. Then add electrons.

add OH⁻ instead of H⁺.error: OH⁻ is for basic conditions, not acidic.
add OH⁻ instead of H⁺.fix: Acidic conditions use H⁺. Basic conditions use OH⁻ with extra steps.
add OH⁻ instead of H⁺.action: Check the question: acidic → use H⁺ only. Basic → use H⁺ first, then neutralise with OH⁻.

persistent.gap: You don't have the KOHES steps memorised correctly.
persistent.action: Write KOHES on every practice problem until automatic: Key, Oxygen, Hydrogen, Electrons, States.

balancing_oxygen.name: Balancing Oxygen with Water
balancing_oxygen.formula: Add H₂O to the side lacking oxygen
balancing_oxygen.correct: To balance oxygen atoms in complex half-equations, add H₂O molecules to the side that needs more oxygen.

add O²⁻ ions.error: O²⁻ ions don't exist freely in solution.
add O²⁻ ions.fix: Oxygen is balanced using water molecules, H₂O, not oxide ions.
add O²⁻ ions.action: Water is the oxygen source in aqueous redox. Add H₂O to the oxygen-deficient side.

add O₂ molecules.error: O₂ gas is not typically used to balance half-equations.
add O₂ molecules.fix: In aqueous solutions, we use H₂O to provide oxygen atoms.
add O₂ molecules.action: Aqueous redox uses water. Count O atoms needed and add that many H₂O molecules.

add H₂O to both sides.error: Add water to only ONE side—the side lacking oxygen.
add H₂O to both sides.fix: Identify which side has fewer oxygen atoms. Add H₂O only to that side.
add H₂O to both sides.action: Example: MnO₄⁻ → Mn²⁺ has 4 O on left, 0 on right. Add 4H₂O to RIGHT.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly identifying which side needs water molecules.
persistent.action: Count oxygen atoms on each side. Add H₂O to the side with fewer oxygen atoms.

balancing_hydrogen_acidic.name: Balancing Hydrogen with H⁺ (Acidic)
balancing_hydrogen_acidic.formula: Add H⁺ to the side lacking hydrogen
balancing_hydrogen_acidic.correct: After adding water, balance hydrogen by adding H⁺ ions to the side that needs more hydrogen atoms.

add H₂ gas.error: H₂ gas is not used to balance half-equations.
add H₂ gas.fix: In acidic conditions, hydrogen comes from H⁺ ions in solution.
add H₂ gas.action: Acidic solutions contain H⁺. Use these to balance hydrogen, not H₂ gas.

add OH⁻ ions.error: OH⁻ is for basic conditions, not acidic.
add OH⁻ ions.fix: Acidic conditions = H⁺. Basic conditions = OH⁻ plus extra steps.
add OH⁻ ions.action: Read the question carefully: acidic → H⁺, basic → OH⁻ method.

add H⁺ to the same side as H₂O.error: H⁺ goes on the OPPOSITE side to where you added H₂O.
add H⁺ to the same side as H₂O.fix: H₂O adds oxygen AND hydrogen to one side. H⁺ balances that hydrogen on the other side.
add H⁺ to the same side as H₂O.action: If you added H₂O to the right, the new H atoms need balancing. Add H⁺ to the left.

persistent.gap: You're adding H⁺ to the wrong side of the equation.
persistent.action: After adding H₂O, count H on each side. Add H⁺ to the side with fewer H atoms.

basic_conditions_method.name: Extra Steps for Basic Conditions
basic_conditions_method.formula: After KOHES: add OH⁻ to both sides, combine H⁺ + OH⁻ → H₂O, cancel water
basic_conditions_method.correct: In basic conditions, complete KOHES first, then add OH⁻ ions to BOTH sides to neutralise H⁺, combine H⁺ and OH⁻ to form H₂O, and cancel water molecules.

use OH⁻ instead of H⁺ from the start.error: You still start with KOHES using H⁺, then convert to basic.
use OH⁻ instead of H⁺ from the start.fix: Basic method: do KOHES with H⁺ first, then neutralise by adding OH⁻ to both sides.
use OH⁻ instead of H⁺ from the start.action: Start as if acidic, then add the same number of OH⁻ to BOTH sides to neutralise.

add OH⁻ to only one side.error: OH⁻ must be added to BOTH sides equally.
add OH⁻ to only one side.fix: Adding OH⁻ to both sides keeps the equation balanced while neutralising H⁺.
add OH⁻ to only one side.action: If you have 14H⁺, add 14OH⁻ to LEFT and 14OH⁻ to RIGHT.

skip the water cancellation step.error: You must combine H⁺ + OH⁻ and cancel excess water.
skip the water cancellation step.fix: H⁺ + OH⁻ → H₂O. This creates water that may cancel with existing H₂O on the other side.
skip the water cancellation step.action: After combining, count H₂O on each side and cancel the smaller number from both.

persistent.gap: You're not completing all steps for basic conditions.
persistent.action: Write the extended sequence: KOHES, then OH⁻ to both sides, then combine, then cancel.

charge_balance.name: Balancing Charges with Electrons
charge_balance.formula: Add electrons to the more positive side
charge_balance.correct: To balance charges, count the total charge on each side and add electrons to the MORE POSITIVE side to make both sides equal.

add electrons to the more negative side.error: Adding electrons to the negative side makes it more negative—wrong direction.
add electrons to the more negative side.fix: Electrons are negative. Add them to the positive side to bring charges into balance.
add electrons to the more negative side.action: If left = +12 and right = +6, add 6e⁻ to the left to get +6 on both sides.

add electrons to make both sides zero.error: Charges don't have to equal zero, just equal each other.
add electrons to make both sides zero.fix: Final charges can be +2 and +2, or -3 and -3. They just need to match.
add electrons to make both sides zero.action: Example: Fe³⁺ + e⁻ → Fe²⁺. Charges are +2 on each side. Not zero, but balanced.

add electrons to both sides.error: Electrons go on only ONE side of a half-equation.
add electrons to both sides.fix: Add electrons to just the more positive side. Electrons on both sides would cancel.
add electrons to both sides.action: Calculate charge difference. Add that many electrons to the positive side only.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly calculating and balancing charges.
persistent.action: Practice: sum charges on left, sum on right, find difference, add e⁻ to positive side.

combining_half_equations.name: Combining Half-Equations
combining_half_equations.formula: Balance electrons, then add equations, cancel electrons
combining_half_equations.correct: To combine half-equations: multiply to make electron numbers equal, add the equations together, then cancel electrons from both sides.

add equations without balancing electron.error: Electrons must be equal before combining or they won't cancel.
add equations without balancing electron.fix: Find the lowest common multiple of electrons. Multiply each equation to reach that number.
add equations without balancing electron.action: If one has 2e⁻ and one has 3e⁻, multiply by 3 and 2 respectively to get 6e⁻ each.

multiply only one half-equation.error: Sometimes both equations need multiplying to balance electrons.
multiply only one half-equation.fix: Find LCM. If electrons are 2 and 3, LCM = 6. Multiply first by 3, second by 2.
multiply only one half-equation.action: Check: do both half-equations now have the same number of electrons?

leave electrons in the final equation.error: Electrons must completely cancel in the overall equation.
leave electrons in the final equation.fix: In a full redox equation, electrons are transferred, not created or destroyed.
leave electrons in the final equation.action: After combining, electrons on left should equal electrons on right, then cancel all.

persistent.gap: You're not correctly balancing and cancelling electrons when combining.
persistent.action: Practice: write electron count for each half-equation, find LCM, multiply, add, cancel.

state_symbols.name: State Symbols in Half-Equations
state_symbols.correct: State symbols: ions are aqueous (aq), water is liquid (l), pure metals are solid (s), gases are (g), and electrons have NO state symbol.

electrons are aqueous.error: Electrons don't have a state symbol.
electrons are aqueous.fix: Electrons are not a substance—they're subatomic particles. No state needed.
electrons are aqueous.action: Write electrons as just 'e⁻' with no brackets or state symbol.

water is aqueous.error: Water is the solvent, so it's liquid (l), not aqueous.
water is aqueous.fix: Aqueous means 'dissolved in water'. Water can't be dissolved in itself.
water is aqueous.action: Always write H₂O(l). Aqueous (aq) is for dissolved ions and molecules.

H⁺ is liquid.error: H⁺ ions are dissolved in water, so they're aqueous.
H⁺ is liquid.fix: All ions in solution are aqueous (aq), including H⁺, OH⁻, and metal ions.
H⁺ is liquid.action: Ions = (aq). Only pure water itself is (l).

persistent.gap: You're not correctly assigning state symbols.
persistent.action: Make a reference card: ions → (aq), H₂O → (l), metals → (s), gases → (g), e⁻ → none.

identifying_oxidation_reduction.name: Identifying Oxidation vs Reduction
identifying_oxidation_reduction.formula: OILRIG: Oxidation Is Loss, Reduction Is Gain
identifying_oxidation_reduction.correct: Use OILRIG: Oxidation Is Loss of electrons (electrons on right), Reduction Is Gain of electrons (electrons on left).

oxidation is gain of electrons.error: Reversed. Oxidation is LOSS of electrons.
oxidation is gain of electrons.fix: OILRIG: Oxidation Is Loss. The species loses electrons (becomes more positive).
oxidation is gain of electrons.action: Oxidation: Zn → Zn²⁺ + 2e⁻. Zinc lost electrons, was oxidised.

reduction is loss of electrons.error: Reversed. Reduction is GAIN of electrons.
reduction is loss of electrons.fix: OILRIG: Reduction Is Gain. The species gains electrons (becomes less positive).
reduction is loss of electrons.action: Reduction: Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu. Copper gained electrons, was reduced.

look at oxygen atoms to determine type.error: While historically related to oxygen, that's not how we identify redox today.
look at oxygen atoms to determine type.fix: Use electron transfer: loss = oxidation, gain = reduction. Forget the oxygen rule.
look at oxygen atoms to determine type.action: Check electron position. Left side = reduction. Right side = oxidation.

persistent.gap: You're confusing oxidation and reduction definitions.
persistent.action: Write OILRIG on every redox problem until automatic.

simple_half_equations.title: Writing Simple Half-Equations
simple_half_equations.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of simple half-equations involving a single element.

sentences.text: In a redox half-equation, oxidation is represented by electrons appearing on the {{d1}} of the equation because oxidation is the {{d2}} of electrons.

d1.tooltip: OILRIG: Oxidation Is Loss. Lost items appear as products.

d2.tooltip: OILRIG: Oxidation Is Loss, Reduction Is Gain.

sentences.text: For the oxidation of zinc metal to zinc ions, the half-equation is written as Zn(s) → Zn²⁺(aq) + {{d3}}, where the electrons are {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Zn loses 2 electrons to become Zn²⁺. How many electrons are lost?

d4.tooltip: In oxidation, electrons are released by the species being oxidised.

sentences.text: In a reduction half-equation, electrons appear on the {{d5}} as {{d6}} because the species is gaining electrons.

d5.tooltip: Reduction Is Gain. Gained items must be on the reactant side.

d6.tooltip: The species takes in electrons, so electrons are inputs (reactants).

sentences.text: The method for writing simple half-equations follows the acronym {{d7}}, which stands for balance Elements, balance {{d8}}, then add States.

d7.tooltip: This three-letter acronym guides simple half-equation writing.

d8.tooltip: After balancing atoms, you balance the electrical charges using electrons.

sentences.text: When writing state symbols, ions in solution are written as {{d9}}, water is written as {{d10}}, and electrons have {{d11}} state symbol.

d10.tooltip: Water is the liquid solvent, not dissolved in itself.

d11.tooltip: Electrons are subatomic particles, not substances with physical states.

acidic_conditions.title: Balancing Half-Equations in Acidic Conditions
acidic_conditions.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to show your understanding of the KOHES method for acidic conditions.

sentences.text: Complex half-equations contain more than one element and require the {{d1}} method when balancing in acidic conditions.

d1.tooltip: This five-letter acronym guides complex half-equation balancing in acid.

sentences.text: In KOHES, the first step K stands for balancing the {{d2}} element, which is the element that is not {{d3}} or hydrogen.

d2.tooltip: The main element being oxidised or reduced, not O or H.

d3.tooltip: O and H are balanced in later steps using H₂O and H⁺.

sentences.text: To balance oxygen atoms, we add {{d4}} molecules to the side of the equation that is {{d5}} in oxygen.

d4.tooltip: In aqueous solution, water provides the oxygen atoms needed.

d5.tooltip: Add water where there aren't enough oxygen atoms.

sentences.text: After adding water, hydrogen is balanced by adding {{d6}} ions to the side that needs more hydrogen, and this is done in {{d7}} conditions.

d6.tooltip: Acidic solutions contain an abundance of hydrogen ions.

d7.tooltip: H⁺ ions indicate an acidic environment.

sentences.text: For the reduction of MnO₄⁻ to Mn²⁺ in acidic conditions, we need to add {{d8}} water molecules to balance oxygen and {{d9}} H⁺ ions to balance hydrogen.

d8.tooltip: MnO₄⁻ has 4 oxygen atoms. Mn²⁺ has none.

d9.tooltip: 4 H₂O molecules contain 8 hydrogen atoms total.

sentences.text: To balance charges, electrons are added to the {{d10}} side of the equation, and the final step S requires adding {{d11}} to all species.

d10.tooltip: Electrons are negative, so they reduce the positive charge.

d11.tooltip: The S in KOHES stands for States.

basic_conditions.title: Balancing Half-Equations in Basic Conditions
basic_conditions.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to understand how basic conditions differ from acidic conditions.

sentences.text: Balancing half-equations in basic conditions requires additional steps after completing the {{d1}} method.

d1.tooltip: You still start with KOHES, then add extra steps for basic conditions.

sentences.text: After using KOHES, in basic conditions we neutralise the H⁺ ions by adding {{d2}} ions to {{d3}} of the equation.

d2.tooltip: Hydroxide ions neutralise hydrogen ions in basic solutions.

d3.tooltip: Adding to both sides keeps the equation balanced.

sentences.text: When H⁺ and OH⁻ ions are on the same side of the equation, they combine to form {{d4}}, which can then {{d5}} with water on the opposite side.

d4.tooltip: H⁺ + OH⁻ → H₂O is a neutralisation reaction.

d5.tooltip: Same species on both sides can be simplified.

sentences.text: Alkaline batteries operate under {{d6}} conditions, while car batteries operate under {{d7}} conditions.

d6.tooltip: Alkaline = basic. These batteries use hydroxide electrolytes.

d7.tooltip: Car batteries use sulfuric acid as the electrolyte.

sentences.text: For the reduction of Cr₂O₇²⁻ to Cr³⁺ in basic conditions, after completing KOHES with 14H⁺, we add {{d8}} OH⁻ ions to both sides, then combine and cancel {{d9}} water molecules.

d8.tooltip: Add the same number of OH⁻ as there are H⁺ to neutralise them.

combining_equations.title: Combining Half-Equations
combining_equations.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate how to combine oxidation and reduction half-equations.

sentences.text: In a complete redox reaction, the number of electrons {{d1}} by the reducing agent must equal the number of electrons {{d2}} by the oxidising agent.

d1.tooltip: The reducing agent loses electrons (gets oxidised).

d2.tooltip: The oxidising agent gains electrons (gets reduced).

sentences.text: Before combining half-equations, we must find the {{d3}} of the electron numbers and multiply the half-equations to achieve {{d4}} electrons in each.

d3.tooltip: LCM ensures both equations have the same electron count.

d4.tooltip: Equal electrons on each side allows them to cancel.

sentences.text: If one half-equation has 2e⁻ and another has 3e⁻, we multiply the first by {{d5}} and the second by {{d6}} to get 6e⁻ in each.
When the half-equations are added together, the electrons on the left-hand side {{d7}} with those on the right-hand side, leaving no electrons in the final equation.

d7.tooltip: Electrons transfer between species; none are created or destroyed.

sentences.text: For the reaction 2Ag⁺(aq) + Ni(s) → 2Ag(s) + Ni²⁺(aq), the silver half-equation was multiplied by {{d8}} because nickel transfers {{d9}} electrons.

d8.tooltip: Ag⁺ + e⁻ → Ag has 1 electron. Ni → Ni²⁺ + 2e⁻ has 2 electrons.

d9.tooltip: Ni goes from 0 to +2, losing 2 electrons.

simple_half_equations.title: Applying Simple Half-Equation Skills
simple_half_equations.instructions: Apply your understanding of simple half-equations to these scenarios.

sentences.text: When copper(II) ions are reduced to copper metal, the half-equation Cu²⁺(aq) + {{d1}} → Cu(s) shows electrons as {{d2}} because the copper ion is gaining electrons.

d1.tooltip: Cu²⁺ has a 2+ charge. How many electrons to become neutral Cu?

d2.tooltip: Gained electrons must be on the input side.

sentences.text: The half-equation Cl₂(g) + 2e⁻ → 2Cl⁻(aq) represents {{d3}} because electrons are on the {{d4}} of the arrow.

d3.tooltip: Electrons on the left means the species gains electrons.

d4.tooltip: Reactant side = left-hand side of the equation.

sentences.text: Using the ECS method for Fe(s) → Fe³⁺(aq), after balancing the element iron, we add {{d5}} to the {{d6}} to balance charges.

d5.tooltip: Fe goes from 0 to +3. How many electrons lost?

sentences.text: The half-equation Br₂(g) + 2e⁻ → 2Br⁻(aq) has the coefficient 2 in front of Br⁻ because there are {{d7}} bromine atoms on the left, requiring {{d8}} electrons for the charge to balance.
In the half-equation Al(s) → Al³⁺(aq) + 3e⁻, aluminium is the {{d9}} agent because it {{d10}} electrons and causes another species to be reduced.

d9.tooltip: The species that loses electrons is the reducing agent.

d10.tooltip: Electrons on the right = electrons lost by the species.

acidic_conditions.title: Applying KOHES in Acidic Conditions
acidic_conditions.instructions: Apply the KOHES method to balance complex half-equations in acidic conditions.

sentences.text: For the reduction of dichromate Cr₂O₇²⁻ to Cr³⁺ in acidic conditions, the key element is {{d1}} and we need to place a coefficient of {{d2}} in front of Cr³⁺ to balance it.

d1.tooltip: The key element is the one being reduced or oxidised, not O or H.

sentences.text: After balancing chromium in Cr₂O₇²⁻ → 2Cr³⁺, we add {{d3}} H₂O molecules to the {{d4}} to balance the 7 oxygen atoms.

d3.tooltip: 7 oxygen atoms in Cr₂O₇²⁻ need 7 water molecules.

d4.tooltip: The right side has no oxygen, so water goes there.

sentences.text: With 7H₂O on the right side creating 14 hydrogen atoms, we balance by adding {{d5}} to the left side in acidic conditions.
For Cr₂O₇²⁻ + 14H⁺ → 2Cr³⁺ + 7H₂O, the left side has charge {{d6}} and the right side has charge {{d7}}, so we add 6e⁻ to the left.
The complete balanced half-equation in acidic conditions is: 6e⁻ + Cr₂O₇²⁻(aq) + 14H⁺(aq) → 2Cr³⁺(aq) + 7H₂O({{d8}}), showing {{d9}} as a product.

d8.tooltip: Water is always liquid, not aqueous.

d9.tooltip: The O and H balance creates water as a product.

basic_conditions.title: Applying the Basic Conditions Method
basic_conditions.instructions: Apply the extended method for balancing half-equations in basic conditions.

sentences.text: Starting with Cr₂O₇²⁻ + 14H⁺ → 2Cr³⁺ + 7H₂O from acidic conditions, we convert to basic conditions by adding {{d1}} OH⁻ ions to {{d2}} of the equation.

d1.tooltip: Add the same number of OH⁻ as there are H⁺.

d2.tooltip: Adding to both sides maintains balance while neutralising H⁺.

sentences.text: On the left side, 14H⁺ + 14OH⁻ combines to form {{d3}}, while on the right side we now have 7H₂O + {{d4}}OH⁻.

d3.tooltip: H⁺ + OH⁻ → H₂O, and there are 14 of each.

d4.tooltip: We added 14OH⁻ to the right side.

sentences.text: After combining H⁺ and OH⁻, we have 14H₂O on the left and 7H₂O + 14OH⁻ on the right, so we can cancel {{d5}} water molecules from each side.

d5.tooltip: Cancel the smaller number of H₂O from both sides.

sentences.text: The final balanced equation in basic conditions becomes: 6e⁻ + Cr₂O₇²⁻(aq) + {{d6}}H₂O(l) → 2Cr³⁺(aq) + {{d7}}OH⁻(aq).

d6.tooltip: 14 - 7 = 7 water molecules remain on the left.

d7.tooltip: The OH⁻ ions remain on the right after cancellation.

sentences.text: Comparing acidic and basic conditions for the same reaction, in acidic we have H⁺ as a {{d8}}, while in basic we have H₂O as a {{d9}} and OH⁻ as a product.

d8.tooltip: H⁺ is consumed in the reaction in acidic conditions.

d9.tooltip: In basic conditions, water is consumed (moves to reactant side).

combining_equations.title: Combining Half-Equations in Practice
combining_equations.instructions: Practice combining oxidation and reduction half-equations to form overall redox equations.

sentences.text: To combine Ag⁺(aq) + e⁻ → Ag(s) with Ni(s) → Ni²⁺(aq) + 2e⁻, we must multiply the silver half-equation by {{d1}} to balance the {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Silver has 1 electron, nickel has 2. Multiply silver by 2.

d2.tooltip: Electrons must be equal before combining.

sentences.text: After multiplying, we have 2Ag⁺(aq) + 2e⁻ → 2Ag(s) and Ni(s) → Ni²⁺(aq) + 2e⁻. Adding these gives 2Ag⁺(aq) + Ni(s) → 2Ag(s) + Ni²⁺(aq), with electrons {{d3}}.

d3.tooltip: 2e⁻ on left cancels with 2e⁻ on right.

sentences.text: For the reaction between Al and Cu²⁺, the half-equations are: Al → Al³⁺ + 3e⁻ and Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu. The LCM of 3 and 2 is {{d4}}, so we multiply accordingly.

d4.tooltip: The smallest number divisible by both 3 and 2 is 6.

sentences.text: Multiplying Al → Al³⁺ + 3e⁻ by {{d5}} and Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu by {{d6}} gives 6 electrons in each half-equation.
The final combined equation is {{d7}}Al(s) + {{d8}}Cu²⁺(aq) → {{d7}}Al³⁺(aq) + {{d8}}Cu(s).

simple_half_equations.title: Mastering Simple Half-Equations
simple_half_equations.instructions: Demonstrate mastery by identifying and correcting common misconceptions about simple half-equations.

sentences.text: A student writes Na(s) → Na⁺(aq) + e⁻ and correctly identifies this as {{d1}} because electrons appear as {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Electrons on the right = loss of electrons = oxidation.

d2.tooltip: Right side of the equation = products.

sentences.text: The half-equation for the reduction of Fe³⁺ to Fe²⁺ is Fe³⁺(aq) + {{d3}} → Fe²⁺(aq), requiring only {{d4}} electron because the charge changes by one unit.

d3.tooltip: +3 to +2 is a change of 1 in charge.

sentences.text: A common error is writing I₂ + e⁻ → 2I⁻, but this is incorrect because the charges don't balance. The correct equation has {{d5}} on the left to give a total charge of {{d6}} on each side.

d5.tooltip: 2I⁻ has total charge -2. Left side needs 0 + (-2) = -2.

sentences.text: In the half-equation Mg(s) → Mg²⁺(aq) + 2e⁻, magnesium acts as the {{d7}} agent and the Mg²⁺ ion and electrons together form a {{d8}}.

d7.tooltip: Magnesium loses electrons, enabling another species to gain them.

d8.tooltip: Mg/Mg²⁺ differ by electrons, forming a redox couple.

sentences.text: When balancing Mn²⁺(aq) → Mn(s), the half-equation is Mn²⁺(aq) + {{d9}} → Mn(s), with electrons on the {{d10}} because this is a reduction reaction.

d9.tooltip: Mn²⁺ to Mn means gaining 2 electrons.

acidic_conditions.title: Mastering Acidic Conditions
acidic_conditions.instructions: Apply advanced understanding of the KOHES method and troubleshoot common errors.

sentences.text: A student attempts to balance MnO₄⁻ → Mn²⁺ by first adding H⁺, but this is incorrect. The KOHES method requires balancing {{d1}} before {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: KOHES: K-O-H-E-S. Oxygen comes before Hydrogen.

d2.tooltip: Adding H₂O creates H atoms that then need balancing with H⁺.

sentences.text: For the oxidation of H₂SO₃ to SO₄²⁻ in acidic conditions, after balancing S and O with water, we find the sulfate side has {{d3}} more hydrogen atoms, requiring H⁺ on the {{d4}} side.

d3.tooltip: H₂SO₃ has 2H. After adding H₂O for O balance, count H difference.

d4.tooltip: H⁺ goes to the side lacking hydrogen.

sentences.text: The balanced half-equation for MnO₄⁻ → Mn²⁺ in acidic conditions is: MnO₄⁻(aq) + 8H⁺(aq) + {{d5}} → Mn²⁺(aq) + 4H₂O(l). This is a {{d6}} reaction because electrons are reactants.

d5.tooltip: Left: -1 + 8 = +7. Right: +2. Difference: 5 electrons to left.

d6.tooltip: Electrons on the left = gained = reduction.

sentences.text: If a student forgets to include state symbols in their final answer, they would lose marks because states are required by step {{d7}} of KOHES and indicate whether species are {{d8}}.

d7.tooltip: S is the final step: States.

d8.tooltip: States tell us the physical form of each species.

sentences.text: For Fe²⁺ → Fe³⁺ + e⁻ and MnO₄⁻ + 8H⁺ + 5e⁻ → Mn²⁺ + 4H₂O, combining requires multiplying the iron equation by {{d9}} to balance the {{d10}} electrons from permanganate.

d9.tooltip: Iron produces 1e⁻, permanganate needs 5e⁻. Multiply iron by 5.

basic_conditions.title: Mastering Basic Conditions
basic_conditions.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of the basic conditions method and common pitfalls.

sentences.text: A key difference between acidic and basic half-equations is that basic conditions have {{d1}} as a product instead of H⁺ as a reactant, and may have {{d2}} as a reactant.

d1.tooltip: After neutralising H⁺, hydroxide ions appear on the product side.

d2.tooltip: Water often moves to the reactant side in basic conditions.

sentences.text: A student incorrectly adds OH⁻ only to the side with H⁺. The correct procedure is to add {{d3}} OH⁻ ions to {{d4}} to maintain equation balance.

d3.tooltip: Same number of OH⁻ to both sides keeps the equation balanced.

d4.tooltip: Adding to both sides is like adding zero—it doesn't unbalance anything.

sentences.text: When converting the acidic equation MnO₄⁻ + 8H⁺ + 5e⁻ → Mn²⁺ + 4H₂O to basic conditions, we add 8OH⁻ to both sides. On the left, 8H⁺ + 8OH⁻ becomes {{d5}}, while the right becomes 4H₂O + {{d6}}.

d6.tooltip: We added 8OH⁻ to the right side.

sentences.text: After combining and cancelling, the basic conditions equation is: MnO₄⁻ + {{d7}}H₂O + 5e⁻ → Mn²⁺ + {{d8}}OH⁻.

d7.tooltip: 8H₂O on left - 4H₂O cancelled = 4H₂O remaining on left.

d8.tooltip: 8OH⁻ remains on the right after cancellation.

sentences.text: Comparing the same reduction in both conditions, acidic uses {{d9}} molecules of water as product, while basic uses {{d10}} molecules of water as reactant—a complete reversal of water's role.

combining_equations.title: Mastering Combined Redox Equations
combining_equations.instructions: Apply all skills to write and verify complete overall redox equations.

sentences.text: To write the overall equation for a lead-acid battery reaction, we combine Pb → Pb²⁺ + 2e⁻ with PbO₂ + 4H⁺ + 2e⁻ → Pb²⁺ + 2H₂O. Since both have {{d1}} electrons, we can add directly without {{d2}}.

d2.tooltip: Equal electrons means no multiplication needed.

sentences.text: When combining 5Fe²⁺ → 5Fe³⁺ + 5e⁻ with MnO₄⁻ + 8H⁺ + 5e⁻ → Mn²⁺ + 4H₂O, the electrons cancel because both half-equations have been adjusted to have {{d3}} electrons, resulting in {{d4}} electrons in the final equation.

d3.tooltip: Iron was multiplied by 5 to give 5e⁻.

sentences.text: The final equation 5Fe²⁺ + MnO₄⁻ + 8H⁺ → 5Fe³⁺ + Mn²⁺ + 4H₂O shows that {{d5}} iron(II) ions react with {{d6}} permanganate ion in acidic conditions.

d5.tooltip: Coefficient of Fe²⁺ in the final equation is 5.

sentences.text: To verify our combined equation is balanced, we check that the total charge on the left ({{d7}}) equals the total charge on the right ({{d8}}).
In this titration reaction, MnO₄⁻ acts as the {{d9}} agent because it {{d10}} electrons, while Fe²⁺ acts as the reducing agent.

d9.tooltip: MnO₄⁻ gains electrons, causing Fe²⁺ to lose electrons.

d10.tooltip: The oxidising agent is reduced (gains electrons).

oxidation_electron_position.title: Electron Position in Oxidation
oxidation_electron_position.content: In oxidation half-equations, electrons appear on the RIGHT-HAND side (product side) because oxidation is the LOSS of electrons. The mnemonic OILRIG helps: Oxidation Is Loss, Reduction Is Gain. When a species is oxidised, it releases electrons, making them products of the reaction.
keyPoints: Lost electrons appear as products (right side)

reduction_electron_position.title: Electron Position in Reduction
reduction_electron_position.content: In reduction half-equations, electrons appear on the LEFT-HAND side (reactant side) because reduction is the GAIN of electrons. The species being reduced accepts electrons, so electrons must be inputs to the reaction.
keyPoints: Gained electrons appear as reactants (left side)

simple_half_equation_steps.title: The ECS Method
simple_half_equation_steps.content: For simple half-equations involving only one element, use the ECS method: (1) Balance Elements by adding coefficients, (2) Balance Charges by adding electrons to the more positive side, (3) Add States to all species. This method works for reactions like metal ion formation or halogen reduction.
keyPoints: C = Charges (add electrons to positive side)

kohes_method.title: The KOHES Method for Acidic Conditions
kohes_method.content: Complex half-equations (containing multiple elements) in acidic conditions use KOHES: (K) Balance the Key element (not O or H), (O) Balance Oxygen with H₂O, (H) Balance Hydrogen with H⁺, (E) Balance Electrons, (S) Add States. This systematic approach ensures correct balancing.
keyPoints: K = Key element (the one being oxidised/reduced)

basic_conditions_method.title: Balancing in Basic Conditions
basic_conditions_method.content: For basic (alkaline) conditions, first complete KOHES as if acidic, then: (1) Add the same number of OH⁻ to BOTH sides as there are H⁺, (2) Combine H⁺ + OH⁻ → H₂O, (3) Cancel water molecules that appear on both sides. This converts H⁺ to H₂O and introduces OH⁻ as a product.
keyPoints: Start with KOHES as if acidic
Add equal OH⁻ to both sides

charge_balance.title: Balancing Charges with Electrons
charge_balance.content: To balance charges in half-equations, calculate the total charge on each side and add electrons to the MORE POSITIVE side. Electrons carry negative charge (-1 each), so adding them reduces the total charge. The final charges don't need to be zero—they just need to be equal on both sides.
keyPoints: Add electrons to the more positive side
Charges must be equal, not necessarily zero

combining_half_equations.title: Combining Half-Equations
combining_half_equations.content: To write an overall redox equation: (1) Write both balanced half-equations, (2) Find the lowest common multiple of the electron numbers, (3) Multiply each half-equation to achieve equal electrons, (4) Add the equations together, (5) Cancel electrons (they should completely cancel). The final equation shows no electrons.
keyPoints: Verify: same total charge on both sides

state_symbols.title: State Symbols in Half-Equations
state_symbols.content: State symbols indicate the physical state of each species: (s) = solid, (l) = liquid, (g) = gas, (aq) = aqueous (dissolved in water). All ions in solution are (aq), water is always (l), and electrons have NO state symbol because they are subatomic particles, not substances.

identifying_oxidation_reduction.title: Identifying Oxidation and Reduction
identifying_oxidation_reduction.content: Use OILRIG: Oxidation Is Loss, Reduction Is Gain. In half-equations, identify the type by electron position: electrons on the LEFT = reduction (electrons gained), electrons on the RIGHT = oxidation (electrons lost). The reducing agent is oxidised; the oxidising agent is reduced.
keyPoints: OILRIG: Oxidation Is Loss, Reduction Is Gain

balancing_oxygen.title: Balancing Oxygen with Water
balancing_oxygen.content: In complex half-equations, oxygen atoms are balanced by adding water (H₂O) molecules to the side that lacks oxygen. This is because in aqueous solutions, water is the source of oxygen atoms. Count the oxygen atoms on each side and add the required number of H₂O to balance.
keyPoints: Add H₂O to the side with fewer O atoms
Each H₂O provides one O atom
This step introduces H atoms to balance next

balancing_hydrogen_acidic.title: Balancing Hydrogen in Acidic Conditions
balancing_hydrogen_acidic.content: After adding water to balance oxygen, hydrogen atoms must be balanced using H⁺ ions (in acidic conditions). Count the total hydrogen on each side and add H⁺ to the side with fewer hydrogen atoms. This is appropriate because acidic solutions contain an abundance of H⁺ ions.
keyPoints: Add H⁺ to the side with fewer H atoms
H⁺ goes on the OPPOSITE side to where H₂O was added
